newsitem.title: USA: Kmart sees Q2 net below year-ago results.
newsitem.headline: Kmart sees Q2 net below year-ago results.

text.p: Kmart Corp said Wednesday that continued high markdowns on women's apparel will hold its second quarter net income below its year-ago profit of $34 million, or $0.07 a share.

"Currently, we expect that Kmart will report a profitable second quarter, but below last year's performance," Kmart Chairman Floyd Hall said in a statement accompanying the retailer's June sales results.

Excluding the discontinued Builders Square unit, Kmart reported that its sales for the five-week period ended July 2 increased 3.5 percent over a year earlier to $3.142 billion with sales for stores open throughout both periods up 5.3 percent.
Hall said the overall sales were running as expected and showed progress in home fashions and seasonal areas, such as outdoor furniture, fans and air conditioners.

"While sales of women's apparel improved slightly during June, clearance markdowns continue to be significantly higher than plan," Hall said. "As a result, Kmart's solid performance in other merchandise areas will be more than offset by margin erosion specifically tied to women's apparel."
He added that Kmart is disappointed with its poor performance in women's apparel and is taking steps to "get it right in this critical area."
The company is actively searching for a new senior vice president of apparel and a divisional vice president for its women's wear business and expects to have both positions filled soon.
Stephen Ross, Kmart's apparel chief, left the comany in June as the result of a mutual agreement with top management following disappointing clothing sales.
Hall said Kmart's consumables business performed well in June, aided by the conversion of 118 additional stores to the new Big Kmart format, which feature large "pantry" sections of consumable items.
